comments.body: I use Fedora (GNU/Linux). I'll just vote and say Ubuntu this time, though.
I fully support democratic socialism. I highly recommend everyone having a look at the Pirate Party, specifically, the Australian Pirate Party: pirateparty.org.au (Clearnet)

I'd recommend Fedora (GNU/Linux) for users who like a semi-rolling distro, aka wanting to have new features quickly, but rather live near the edge. Fedora and most GNU/Linux distributions are also open-source and do not violate one's privacy, unlike other OSs. Due to the fact that it's open-source, it's therefore more secure as the code can be peer reviewed. The downside with Fedora and most GNU/Linux OSs is that *some* software from other OSs (ex. Android, I'd suggest you look at Anbox.io, which integrates Android apps into your system), mainly Windows, simply do not run.
Well yes, they're an unidentified flying object. That object could be anything, such as a rock.

I'm calling the election: [The Conservatives will be returned, but as a minority government.](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1White24UrrwQrD86o6Vrc1apgZ1x1o51/1GgNo3CmxPd7n2pMSF3uyqf1XHvgtTUqCe/1496978774)

I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you’re referring to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I’ve recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX.
Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called “Linux”, and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project. There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use.
Linux is the kernel: the program in the system that allocates the machine’s resources to the other programs that you run. The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called “Linux” distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux.﻿

It appears it's more than likely we'll see a National + NZ First government. We could end up with a Labour + Greens + NZ First government, though. It'll all depend on how NZ First decides to form government with.
They have different purposes, so it's hard to say if any are better than the others.
It looks like I was wrong when I said we may get a National + NZ First government. We will be getting a Labour + NZ First coalition government with the Greens agreeing on supply and confidence.

If we change this system to Single Transferable Vote the results would be different. Capitalism would not have won as it did not reach 50% on first-preferences. Socialism would have received the Communist votes as Socialism is closer to their views than Capitalism. Therefore, with the Communist preferences, on 2PP, Socialism would have received roughly 59%, which is a win.
Feminism covers the rights of all genders.
